title: How are Native Americans and American Indians different? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Two terms for the same thing. I’m half Indian, and that’s how I refer to myself. I don’t worry about people confusing me with someone from New Delhi, and from my experience the term “Native American” is generally championed by white people who decided “Indian” was offensive to us. I find “Native American” a ridiculous term, myself. Before white people got here, this place wasn’t called America. So no, we weren’t native to “America”. Same reason I leave “American” off the term “Indian”. If it’s so offensive, why do we still call our own organizations “Indian”, like NIVA (Northwest Indian Veteran’s Association)? And finally, I LIKE the term Indian. It’s a nice reminder of what a shitty navigator/explorer Columbus was. As I like to tell my Italian wife, “Only Italians would give a guy a holiday for getting lost.”

“Native” is an old derogatory term denoting inferior races. That racist term then recycled in a PC way that disrespects First Ones and those of us of First Ones Ancestral Lineage. That “N-A” term is by far more racist than calling Blacks by the ’n’ word. And so should not be used ever. It represents the pc’s final solution to the First Ones problem and is quite evil in both its design and intent. Where “American Indian” is still respectful, used by elders but in need of tweaking or replacement. “First People” is okay but off the mark. First Ones works across the globe as Australia has its First Ones as does Hawaii, Mexico, Canada and America. The PC had a problem with First Ones and their FOAL. They needed a way to keep America’s FO and FOAL at the back of their social justice bus and off the reparations list.
